chapter.title: Control panels and infrastructure
chapter.para: Operation of the vessel is supported by two principal control panels and a data communications infrastructure which allows inter-alia controls to operate remote devices and instruments to gather data from remote sensors.
The vessel uses the NMEA 2000 standard network architecture for data communication between critical systems and notably for operation of remote equipment via NMEA 2000 'switchbank' protocols.

Ethernet networks, both wired and wireless, are used to support technical, domestic and entertainment activities and proprietary network systems are used to interconnect components when there is no open or generic alternative.
The vessel supports wide-area communication and control via SMS, email and some proprietary protocols.

sect2.title: NMEA 2000
sect2.para: The vessel is equipped with two NMEA 2000 buses and a dedicated industrial PC responsible for operation of NMEA related features.

listitem.para: NMEA bus 0 supports instrumentation and control of the ship's domestic or 'house' systems.
If this bus is not permanently enabled then very few of the ship's systems can be operated.
NMEA bus 1 supports instrumentation and control related to navigation of the vessel.

sect2.para: The two networks are bridged at the helm so that communication on one is visible on the other, but are powered separately. When navigation instrumentation and control is not required then NMEA bus 1 should be switched off at the domestic panel to conserve battery charge.

Most non-local switching activities on the ship are mediated over NMEA 2000 and operating a switch at the helm will cause a signal to be sent over the NMEA 2000 network which causes a relay in a remote part of the vessel to change state. The relationship between switch operation and relay state change is mapped through a programmable NMEA controller which also supports some automatic convenience functions: for example, the controller can monitor waste tank levels and issue SMS or email alerts or initiate an automatic waste-discharge if a tank overflow is imminent. The controller PC is accessible at http://192.168.1.120:2000/.

sect2.title: Ethernet
sect2.para: The ship uses Ethernet as its default communication system for non-critical data communications. In addition to a conventional file server, a DLNA server distributes music and video and real-time TV from satellite and terrestrial receivers over ipTV.
Some ship systems are available on the local Ethernet and some more widely available.

sect3.title: Wired ethernet
sect3.para: A wired Ethernet network reaches all parts of the living accommodation. An intelligent switch with QoS ensures that bandwidth is managed in favour of critical services.

sect3.title: WiFi
sect3.para: The ship supports two physical WiFi networks and three virtual networks. An on-board network (SSID=BEATRICE) is simply an extension of the ship's wired Ethernet. An external WiFi network, switchable at the helm, supports deck communications over VoIP (SSID=BEATRICE-VOIP) and a public presence (SSID=BEATRICE-GUEST) as well as providing a high-gain connection for access to remote wireless hubs.

sect3.title: WAN connectivity
sect3.para: The ship supports access to the Internet by both WiFi and cellular connections.

sect2.title: Email and SMS interfaces
sect2.para: The ship's NMEA controller offers some services over email and SMS. Alerts for certain conditions can be selected for email or SMS notification and some controls can be operated by SMS and/or email.

sect2.title: Proprietary networks
sect2.para: The only proprietary netwoks on the vessel are the Victron VE-bus which is used for communication between the charger-inverter and various control panels and the Webasto network supporting the chiller and space environmental controls.

sect2.title: Domestic panel
sect2.para: The domestic panel, located in the lower companionway, is the ship's primary control panel bringigng together all of the ship's 'house management' functions and providing controls for enabling and disabling most of vessel's systems.
For most switches to actually do anything NMEA BUS 0 must be enabled.

sect3.title: Instruments and control panels
sect3.para:
The domestic panel incorporates three sub-panels concerned primarily with the ship's domestic battery bank and associated systems.
The Color Control GX is also able to display tank level information.
Refer to the manufacturer's user manuals for information on the operation of these devices.

sect2.title: Helm panel
sect2.para: The helm panel (see ) brings together important controls and instrumentation mainly concerned with navigation of the vessel.

The helm panel is enabled from the domestic panel, HELM, NMEA BUS 0
Only required for access to tank level data , NMEA BUS 1 and VHF
Required for VHF radio and AIS operation controls must be switched ON for the helm panel to be fully functional.

Non-navigation and safety features (including a multi-channel alarm system which alerts a range of critical operating conditions) of the helm panel are available at all times irrespective of the state of domestic panel controls.

sect3.title: Helm alarm system
sect3.para: The alarm system has ten input channels. A signal on any channel will trigger an audible and visual signals at the alarm annunciator; the audible component of an alarm can be cancelled by operating the SILENCE control (the visual alarm component will remain active until the fault or safety condition which triggered the alarm is removed).

sect3.title: Instruments and control panels
sect3.para: The ship's helm panel is the primary location for navigation instrumentation and control and incorporates switches, indicators (both described below) and the following discrete instruments and control panels.
Refer to the manufacturer's user manuals for information on the operation of these devices.

sect3.title: Indicator and switch controls
sect3.para: The helm panel indicators and switches are water resistant, mult-function, industrial devices rated for 24VDC operation at up to 30A. Background and function illumination is by LED.

Some of the panel switches handle operating currents (for example the windscreen-wiper switch), but the majority switch a signal in the mA range sufficient to operate an NMEA 2000 switch bank interface or, occasionally, a remote relay.

sect4.title: Indicators
sect4.para: Carling VP series, two-segment, LED indicators are used throughout.

listitem.para: The upper indicator segment illuminates when NMEA BUS 0 is powered.
The lower indicator segment illuminates when NMEA BUS 1 is powered.
The ship's NMEA busses are switched at the domestic panel and for navigational use of the helm use both indicator segments should be lit.
The upper indicator segment illuminates when VHF systems are enabled (this includes the ship's primary maritime VHF transceiver and the vessel's AIS transponder).
The lower indicator segment illuminates when the helm panel is enabled.
The ship's VHF sytems and the helm panel are switched at the domestic panel and for navigational use of the helm both indicator segments should be lit.
The upper indicator segment illuminates when either the engine compartment bilge system is disabled or the engine room bilge pump is running.
The lower indicator segment illuminates when either the main compartment bilge system is disabled or the main compartment bilge pump is running.
The upper indicator segment illuminates when the engine compartment temperature exceeds 30C.
The lower indicator segment illuminates when the battery compartment temperature exceeds 30C.
The upper indicator segment illuminates when the waste discharge pump is running.

sect4.title: Switches
sect4.para: Carling L series switches are used throughout.

The switches used in the helm panel are either two-state (single-throw) or three-state (double throw). Two state switches adopt the European convention that the 'up' position is the 'off' state and the other position signals some type of 'on'-ness. Three position switches adopt the 'up is off' convention where possible, but there are a number of situations where this principle cannot apply.

The notation used in this section to describe a two position switch is (upState-downState) and a three position switch (upState-midState-downState). If a switch position is momentary (i.e. the switch must be held in position by finger pressure), then this position is indicated in parentheses: for example (upState-(downState)).

sect5.title: Deck equipment & transmission group
sect5.para: These controls are concerned with heavy equipment under hydraulic operation and with change of transmission mode of operation.
For safety reasons, the ENABLE control must be switched on before other controls in this group will operate.
All of the controls in this group with the exception of the bow-thruster joystick are avaialable on a hand-held deck remote control.

listitem.para: Raises and lowers the anchor. The anchor must be released and the winch engaged before operating this control.
In the ON position the other controls in this group together with the bow-thruster joystick are enabled.
Opens and closes the fore-deck hatch. The hatch must be unlocked before operating this control.
Raises and lowers the mast. The mast guys must be released before operating this control.
In the ON position the transmission is switched to trolling mode, restricting the propellor revolutions for slow speed manoevering.

sect5.title: Domestic group
sect5.para: These controls are concerned with operation of some domestic systems.

listitem.para: In the ON position the aft deck-wash connection will supply raw water rather than the normal potable water from the ship's tank. Note that the forward deck wash connection always supplies potable water.
In the ON position the sewage holding tank will be automatically flushed with raw water when waste discharge completes.

In the AUTO position the sewage holding tank will be automatically discharged when it reaches 90% capacity. If this mode is selected then the holding tank discharge valve and sea-cock must be left open.
In the ON position the sewage discharge pump will operate. Before selecting this mode, the holding tank discharge valve and sea-cock must be open.

sect5.title: Electronics group
sect5.para: These controls operate auxilliary electronic equipment supporting navigation.

listitem.para: In the RECV position the ship's AIS transceiver will receive data from other stations, but will not broadcast this ship's position.
In the TRANSMIT position the transceiver will both receive and transmit AIS data.
In the ON position the ship's radar is powered up.

In the ON position the ship's external WiFi station is powered up. This provides a high-gain antenna for accessing external wireless hotspots and a local wireless hub which supports, amongst other things, VoIP communication amongst crew.

sect5.title: Lighting group
sect5.para: These controls are concerned with operation of lights associated with navigation.

listitem.para: In the ON position the ship's navigation lights (steaming light, stern light, port and starboard lights) are illuminated.
In the ON position the ship's anchor light is illuminated.
In the ON position the ship's work lights (covering the foredeck) are illuminated.
In the ON position the ship's searchlight connection socket is powered.
In the ON position the ship's courtesy lights are illuminated.
In the ON position the ship's red wheelhouse night lighting is illuminated.
In the ON position the windscreen wiper(s) operate. The operating speed and the screen wash are selected by the MODE position. Refer to the windscreen wiper controller manual for more information.
In the ON position the ship's blue board is displayed (moved to its vertical position); in the OFF psoition the board is restored to its horizontal parking position.
In the ON position the ship's horn sounds for the duration the switch is operated.

sect5.title: Panel control group
sect5.para: These controls are concerned with modifying the operation of the helm panel itself.

listitem.para: In the UP position panel background illumination is increased; in the DOWN position panel illumination is decreased.

The SILENCE position cancels the audible component of any active alarm conditions. Note that the alarm indicator lamp will remain illuminated until the cause of the alarm condition is cleared and that any new alarm conditions will cause the audible alarm to sound again).

sect5.title: Safety group
sect5.para: These controls are concerned with operation of environmental safety systems.

listitem.para: This control operates the engine compartment bilge system and should normally be left in the AUTO position. The bilge system is integrated into the ship's helm alarm system and operation of this control may trigger an alert.
In the AUTO position the engine compartment bilge pump will be operated by the system float switch.
In the ON position the engine compartment bilge pump will run continuously.

This control operates the main compartment bilge system and should normally be left in the AUTO position. The bilge system is integrated into the ship's helm alarm system and operation of this control may trigger an alert.
In the AUTO position the main compartment bilge pump will be operated by the system float switch.
In the ON position the main compartment bilge pump will run continuously.
This control operates the engine room ventilation system and should normally be left in the AUTO position.
In the AUTO position the engine room ventilation system will operate when the engine room temperature exceeds the set point on the engine room thermostat.
In the ON position the engine room ventilation system will run continuously.
This control operates the battery compartment ventilation system and should normally be left in the AUTO position.
In the AUTO position the battery compartment ventilation system will operate when the battery compartment temperature exceeds the set point on the battery compartment thermostat.
In the ON position the battery compartment ventilation system will run continuously.
